lcInstruction.p: Once you have installed the DITA OT and the required Java Development Kit, the next step is setting up a folder structure for testing its publishing capabilities. Establishing folders for your DITA source files and published output files will help you avoid confusion and make the process of using the DITA OT run more smoothly.

conbody.p: When you’re working in a standalone DITA OT publishing environment, a well-organized folder structure helps you keep track of your DITA source content. Here are some best practices for setting up your source folders:

li.p: Don’t disrupt the DITA hierarchy. The way you store your DITA content in folders may interfere with the DITA OT’s ability to parse the content and generate some output types from it. Therefore, it is best to avoid storing a map file in a folder that lives below the topic files referenced in the map.
Mange your shared content. If you have topics that are referenced in multiple maps, keep them together in a folder (named something like “shared” or “reused”) where they are easy to find.

conbody.p: By default, the DITA Open Toolkit creates a default output folder named out. If you use the default out folder, be aware that the DITA OT replaces the previously generated output with new output each time you run the DITA OT on the same set of source content for the same type of output. For example, if you generated PDF output from the file b_ducks.ditamap yesterday and you generate PDF output of the same file today, yesterday’s PDF is deleted and today’s PDF replaces it. (If you generate PDF output from a different map, or generate HTML output from the same map, yesterday’s PDF remains in place.)
conbody.note: If you generate a new version of a previously generated PDF file, the DITA OT will not overwrite the previous version if you have it open in Adobe Reader or Acrobat Pro.
conbody.p: To keep the DITA OT from replacing your output, you can set up subfolders in the out folder. When you run the DITA OT, you can instruct it to generate output into the subfolder of your choice. There are many ways you can organize your output subfolders, including:
